Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Image Guidance Systems in Neurosurgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This preclinical randomised study involved 50 novice surgeons

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to one of five groups: (1) no image guidance, (2) triplanar display, (3) always-on solid overlay, (4) always-on wire mesh overlay, and (5) on-demand inverse realism overlay

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various image guidance systems compared to standard surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were time to task completion (seconds) and tool path length (millimeters), measured immediately post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the study design.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This preclinical randomised study involved 50 novice surgeons

Result_Outcome.evidence: Image guidance significantly reduced time to task completion and tool path length compared to no guidance (p < 0.001 and p = 0.003, respectively).
